review.title: Optimal Time-Series Motifs
review.abstract: Motifs are the most repetitive/frequent patterns of a time-series. The discovery of motifs is crucial for practitioners in order to understand and interpret the phenomena occurring in sequential data. Currently, motifs are searched among series sub-sequences, aiming at selecting the most frequently occurring ones. Search-based methods, which try out series sub-sequence as motif candidates, are currently believed to be the best methods in finding the most frequent patterns.

metadata.title: Optimal Time-Series Motifs

sections.text: We show that the search is not optimal because the range of motifs is limited, and instead propose a basic optimization approach that is able to find optimal motifs. We treat the frequency of occurrence as a function and time series motifs as parameters, so we learn the optimal motifs that maximize the frequency function. In contrast to the search, our method is able to detect the most repetitive patterns (therefore optimal), even in cases where they do not explicitly occur as sub-sequences. Experiments with multiple real time series data sets show that the motifs found by our method are much more common than those found by searching for exactly the same distance threshold.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Time is probably the most common type of data occurring in practically all areas of modern life where measurements have time stamps (e.g. physiological and medical, financial, meteorological, acoustic and videographic).In many cases, the underlying patterns of these data sets are not known and visual inspection is often not feasible given the complexity and size of the data. Therefore, the search for the most repetitive methods to do all or part of this work is essential.

sections.heading: 2. RELATED WORK
sections.text: Research into the discovery of time series motifs suffered from a terminological ambiguity. Initially, motifs were defined as the most common patterns in a time series [25]. However, in another publication, the term "motif" was redefined as the closest pair among the series segments [23, 21]. In this essay, we refer to "the most common patterns" [25] when it comes to motifs, whereas the closest pair of series segments is referred to as the "pair motif," as suggested by [19].

sections.heading: 3.3 Searching The Motifs
sections.text: The modern methods described in Section 2, which focus on the search for motifs, are primarily concerned with trying out candidate motifs from the series segments. Although they propose important innovations in their scope (scalability, length analysis, etc.), these techniques are still qualitatively at the upper limit due to the brute force motif search. Algorithm 1 describes a speed-naive, but qualitatively search-optimized implementation of a brute force motif search. We can predict the frequency of all series segments in O (J2L) runtime complexity and then search for the top K motifs based on the calculated frequencies in O (K2JL) time. Since K is typically a small number compared to the segments J > > K, the total brute force search therefore exhibits a complexity of O (J2L + K2JL) and O (J2JL), which is quadratically indicated by the number of motifs we suggest in the sequence (in this case the higher number of the sequence).

sections.heading: 8. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper proposed a new perspective in the learning of time series motifs. In contrast to the current state of the art, where motif candidates from serial segments are sought, our method learns them in a principled optimization. The motif frequency is approximated as a differentiable function, and a method of gradient ascent is proposed to find the motif values that maximize the objective function. To avoid local optima, a random restart strategy is combined with learning the gradient ascent of the motifs. Learned optimal motifs have more segment matches than the motifs found in the search, for the same distance threshold. The optimal motifs represent latent patterns that are not necessarily present as sub-sequences in explicit form, so can identify motifs that are located at the center of the densest hyperspheres, including segment points. Detailed experimental results show that learning optimal motifs always produces more qualitative motifs than they seek.

metadata.abstractText: Motifs are the most repetitive/frequent patterns of a timeseries. The discovery of motifs is crucial for practitioners in order to understand and interpret the phenomena occurring in sequential data. Currently, motifs are searched among series sub-sequences, aiming at selecting the most frequently occurring ones. Search-based methods, which try out series sub-sequence as motif candidates, are currently believed to be the best methods in finding the most frequent patterns. However, this paper proposes an entirely new perspective in finding motifs. We demonstrate that searching is nonoptimal since the domain of motifs is restricted, and instead we propose a principled optimization approach able to find optimal motifs. We treat the occurrence frequency as a function and time-series motifs as its parameters, therefore we learn the optimal motifs that maximize the frequency function. In contrast to searching, our method is able to discover the most repetitive patterns (hence optimal), even in cases where they do not explicitly occur as sub-sequences. Experiments on several real-life time-series datasets show that the motifs found by our method are highly more frequent than the ones found through searching, for exactly the same distance threshold.
